author: arnetheduck
content: when running the beacon chain protocol, there are certain cases when you're behind on blocks (for example during an internet outage and no peers connected) and have to figure out what to do: produce blocks, validate etc.. seemingly, the "best" thing you can do is keep running the protocol, meaning you produce for your own validators and use empty slot transitions to figure that out.. once you reconnect, you'll resync with others, start tallying and in theory, since you weren't finalizing locally, you should be able to reach a stable point by syncing with the others. here's the issue though: for how long do you replay empty blocks? eventually, the empty block processing will cause enough validators to be ejected, and things break down (because committees become empty etc). we could put an arbitrary limit on it but it would be... arbitrary. thoughts?

author: nishant0
content: unless I am missing something, why would you endlessly process skip slots ? wouldn't it be bound by what the current slot is

author: arnetheduck
content: because you're not receiving blocks from others because you're offline, and have to advance the state to the current slot. it's not endlessly, but potentially enough to go on for a good while (like when you restart client after a few days) or your internet is down and then comes back online, and you're not actively monitoring your node because you're busy in real life dealing with a flood, etc

author: arnetheduck
content: there's an upper bound where all validators are kicked, but it's a bit.. extreme. 1 slot of cpu time is more sane, but kind of arbitrary. I'm trying to think of any other bounds that could meaningfully be applied.

author: nishant0
content: gotcha, it makes sense then. This could potentially be handled by your sync protocol. If you do eventually go offline, you could notify your node through status req/resp with other peers. Ex: You were connected to 15 peers previously, and now not a single peer responds to the status request , you could probably restrict running skip slots in that case
